results.title: How to kill your husband
results.brief_description: Shirley’s father, a skilled mechanic and excellent drummer, suffered from heart disease. Shirley retells her father’s history, from the struggles of growing up during the depression to his now proud children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: Narrapumelap
results.brief_description: Narrapumelap - A woman looks at footage of herself as a young girl exploring a graceful old homestead and reflects on how it captures the magical nature of the place and its profound resonance in her memory.

results.title: Passionate pursuits
results.brief_description: This story was created for Robin Hodder’s grandchildren to celebrate his extraordinary achievements as an Olympic sportsman, a husband of 38 years and the world’s greatest dad. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: The Irrepressible Jack Stone
results.brief_description: A heartbreaking but inspiring story about Jack Stone, the kid who lived every moment of his life to the fullest - as told by his mother. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) in partnership with VicHealth. You can create your won Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or go to www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

results.title: Heart disease

Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story / Telling Stories, Building Communities’ Digital Storytelling Project ACMI in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) and supported by Vic Health.

results.title: Max and Noel Oliver's story
results.brief_description:
Alzheimer’s sufferer Max together with his wife Noel have told a story for their granddaughters that celebrates their life together as well as capturing Max’s memories of his son, the children’s father, who died when they were very young. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.
You can create your own Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or visit www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

results.title: Kombi Karma
results.brief_description: Kombi Karma examines a cultural icon through the eyes of a diverse group of VW Kombi van lovers. Rachael travels the Victorian countryside in her Kombi and describes her camping trips as ‘more comfortable than being at home’. David, a Kombi enthusiast for over 30 years, is fascinated by the van’s early beginnings as an economical utilities vehicle in occupied Germany during World War II. Some tell of their love of the Kombi’s idiosyncratic design, ‘I love the box shape because it’s such a practical thing to put things in’. Andrew lovingly restores Kombis and believes ‘once you’re bitten by it, it never really goes away, once you own one you really wouldn’t want to own any other sort of car’. And Jan has learned to love Kombis again after her former partner smashed her newly restored Kombi to pieces with a wood splitter. But perhaps Ben sums it up best when he explains that being a Kombi devotee means that ‘you are someone who enjoys the journey as much as the destination’.

results.brief_description: Combines locational footage with personal reminiscences of Lygon St, Carlton. This film is an excerpt from ‘Stories from the hidden city’, a project conceived and directed by Bagryana Popov, 2000-2002.

results.title: North
results.creator_credit: Christos Linou, Spiro Economopolous and Christos Tsiolkas
results.brief_description: Collingwood - ‘Hit the North. The north is where they put most of the wogs.’ Utilising excerpts from Christos Tsiolkas’ novel ‘Loaded’, ‘North’ is a lyrical and haunting work about space and place in Melbourne’s inner-city northern suburbs. This short work reveals a history of migrant alienation and regret submerged underneath the asphalt, mortar and concrete of the modern Australian city.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christos Linou, Spiro Economopolous and Christos Tsiolkas

results.title: Kitchen sink
results.brief_description: A woman finds an unidentified root growing out of her kitchen sink plug hole. The umbilical like vine grows into an adult male covered in hair from head to toe. The woman shaves the catatonic man and the two begin to play out a primal scene of lust and longing. Alison Maclean’s perverse horror recasts desire in its most primordial and visceral guise.
